Contact Us Contact UsThe Art and Science of Tile Manufacturing Go to Home 1 Home 2 » The Art and Science of Tile Manufacturing Back to Tile TalkA Comprehensive Journey of Tile Manufacturing Tiles have been integral to human civilization for centuries, gracing the floors and walls of palaces, public spaces, and homes. The intricate process of tile production is a fascinating journey of art and science. It intertwines the raw beauty of natural materials with cutting-edge technology and meticulous craftsmanship. In this comprehensive blog, we’ll explore the entire process of tile manufacturing, from the selection of raw materials to the final product, providing insight into one of the world’s most versatile building materials.

Understanding the Ingredients: What Goes In? The journey of tile production begins with its raw materials. Ceramic and porcelain tiles comprise a blend of natural materials, each playing a crucial role in the final product’s quality and characteristics. The key ingredients include: 1 Ball Clay: Ball clay provides the necessary plasticity for the tile mixture, allowing it to be molded and shaped. Its adhesive properties also help the materials bond together before firing. 2 Quartz: Quartz is prized for its hardness and durability. It increases the strength of the tile and helps it resist wear, making it an essential component in ceramic and porcelain tiles. 3 Feldspar: Feldspar, acting as a fluxing agent, helps the materials melt and bond together during firing, contributing to the tile’s final strength and durability. 4 Kaolin: Kaolin enhances mechanical strength and bonding, especially in porcelain tiles. It is also responsible for the white color of tiles, making it a preferred choice in premium-quality tiles. 5 Talc: Talc is added to the tile mixture to improve the smoothness and workability of the clay, making it easier to form and shape during the production process. 6 Bentonite: Bentonite, known for its exceptional binding properties, is crucial in large-format tiles because it holds the tile together during the greenware stage (the stage before firing).

The glaze is a liquid mixture applied to the tile’s surface before firing. It can add color, texture, and a protective layer to the tile, enhancing its aesthetic appeal. Different glazing technologies are used depending on the desired finish:

1 Curtain or Waterfall Glaze: This method is commonly used for single-color ceramic wall tiles. It involves applying a uniform layer of glaze over the tile. In some cases, an engobe layer (a primer) is applied first, which serves as the base for the final decorative layer. 2 Inkjet Technology: A game-changer in the tile industry, inkjet technology allows for precisely applying intricate designs onto tiles. This process resembles a large-format digital printer, where high-resolution images of stones, wood, or concrete (to name a few) are printed onto the tile surface. This technology has revolutionized tile design, enabling factories to offer virtually unlimited design possibilities.

Ceramic kilns are large horizontal ovens with usually a single plane of rollers that move in one direction, advancing the glazed bisques through the different stages. Each type of clay and tile follows a different temperature curve inside the kiln. This temperature might be also affected by the physical size or format of the tile. A number of physical and chemical reactions undergo inside the kiln to form a hardened and ﬁnished tile. Most notably, the glaze fuses and hardens on top of the tile, conferring most kno wn and desired characteristics of ceramic tiles. After ﬁring, AGVs transport again the ﬁred tiles to an intermediate storage area. The ﬁnal stage is the classiﬁcation and packing of the ﬁred tiles.

After glazing, the tiles are ready for firing. Industrial kilns, which can be as long as 150 meters (1.5 football fields), are used to fire the tiles at extremely high temperatures. The specific firing temperature depends on the type of tile: 1 Ceramic Tile: Fired at temperatures ranging from 1000° to 1250°C (1832° to 2282°F). The firing process hardens the tiles while fusing the glaze to the surface. 2 Porcelain Tile: Fired at even higher temperatures, between 1300° and 1346°C (2381° to 2455°F). This higher temperature not only increases the density but ensures that it is more water-resistant than ceramic tiles. This makes porcelain tile ideal for use in areas exposed to moisture.

What causes cracks in tiles? Several factors can contribute to the development of cracks in floor tiles. Understanding these causes is crucial in order to prevent floor tiles cracking effectively. Here are the most common culprits: 1. Hard Impacts One of the primary causes of tile cracking is hard impacts. When heavy objects are dropped onto the tiles or when tiles experience sharp blows, they can develop immediate cracks or weaken over time. It's essential to be cautious when moving furniture or other heavy items on tiled surfaces to avoid damaging the tiles.

2. Incorrect Installation Poor installation practices can lead to tile cracks. Inadequate adhesive coverage, improper grouting, or insufficient substrate preparation are common installation mistakes that can result in cracked tiles. Hiring a professional tile installer who follows proper installation techniques is crucial to prevent such issues. 3. Bearing Too Much Weight Excessive weight or pressure on the tiles can cause them to crack, especially in areas with inadequate structural support. This can happen when heavy objects are placed directly on the tiles or when there is concentrated weight on specific spots. Be mindful of the weight distribution on your tiled surfaces and use proper support to prevent cracking.

4. Cracked Substrate The subfloor or underlying surface plays a significant role in tile durability. If the subfloor is damaged, cracked, or uneven, it can create stress on the tiles above, leading to cracking. Ensure that the substrate is in good condition before tile installation, and address any structural issues promptly. 5. Tiling Over Control Joints Control joints or expansion joints are designed to allow for natural movement and expansion of building materials. Ignoring these joints when tiling can restrict the movement of the flooring, causing stress on the tiles and resulting in cracks and tile popping. Pay attention to control joints and follow proper tiling practices to accommodate for expansion and contraction.

Common causes of adhesive failures Adhesive failures in tile flooring can result from various factors, including: 1 Inadequate surface preparation: A clean, smooth, and dry surface is crucial for effective adhesive bonding. Any dirt, dust, grease, or moisture can weaken the adhesive's grip, leading to tiles coming loose. 2 Incorrect adhesive selection: Using the wrong type of adhesive for your specific tile and substrate can cause bonding issues. Different adhesives are formulated for various materials and conditions, so selecting the appropriate one is vital. 3 Insufficient adhesive application: Applying too little adhesive can create voids beneath the tiles, reducing their adhesion. On the other hand, excessive adhesive can lead to uneven surfaces and weak spots. 4 Environmental factors: Temperature and humidity levels can affect the curing process of adhesives. Extreme conditions can cause the adhesive to set too quickly or too slowly, compromising its effectiveness.

Solutions for adhesive failures Addressing adhesive failures promptly can save your tile flooring from extensive damage. Here are some solutions to consider: 1 Proper surface preparation: Ensure the substrate is clean, dry, and free from contaminants before applying adhesive. The characteristics of the working surface of glazed ceramic tiles have a considerable influence on the mechanical response to the various stresses coming from the environment. Since glazes are essentially a ceramic glass, characterised by rather low toughness values, falling objects and hard sharp particles easily cause surface cracking and material removal, by scratching and chipping [1], with a consequent irreversible degradation of mechanical characteristics and aesthetics. Since the glaze layer is the physical interface between the environment and the ceramic body, its characteristics also determine the service life of the tile. The resistance to surface abrasion of glazed ceramic tiles is usually determined according to the test method specified in the Standard ISO 10545-7 [2]. This test allows to classify the different products on the basis of an apparent visual variation in gloss, caused by a standardised erosive slurry under well established operative conditions. The method it is not able to recognise the wear mechanisms acted during the test and to detect the correlation existing between the characteristics of the material, the glaze, and its abrasion resistance. To clarify the wear response of working surface of glazed tiles, subjected to this test method, the worn areas were analysed using a 3-D optical profilometer. This non-destructive technique allowed to acquire quantitative 3-D images and to measure roughness, waviness and curvature of the worn surface areas. In this way, the mechanisms of material removal have been defined, stage by stage, and the evolution of the surface wear deterioration was explained. Experimental Procedures

For the present study, two commercial single-fired glazed ceramic tiles of different colour, blue and white, were chosen. They were respectively labelled BT and WT. The hardness of the glazed surface of the samples was measured by a hardness tester (Zwick, 3212, Germany), equipped with a Vickers indenter at the following indentation loads 1.95, 2.94, 4.90, 9.81 and 19.62N. At least ten valid impressions for each load were considered. The thickness of the glaze layers was measured via optical microscope observations of polished cross sections of suitable specimens. The comparison, between these values and the depth of the impressions [3], allowed to exclude the contribution of the ceramic body. The resistance to surface abrasion of the glazed ceramic tiles was determined according to the test method specified in the Standard ISO 10545-7 [2]. The test consists in the abrasion, by a standardised abrasive slurry contained in a metal holder, of the working surface of suitable specimens, 100x100mm in dimensions, cut from the glazed tiles to be tested. The erosive slurry, the composition of which is reported in Table 1, consists of steel balls of different diameters, aluminium oxide and distilled water. The system rotates with an eccentricity of 22.5mm for fixed numbers of revolutions 100, 150, 600, 750, 1500, 2100, 6000 and 12000, corresponding to different abrasion stages. At the end of each stage, the specimen is observed following standardised conditions. The determination of the abrasion class, based on the lowest number of revolutions, inducing an apparent visual variation in gloss, was also determined. The worn areas of all the specimens, were analysed using a 3-D optical profilometer, (New View 5000, Zygo Corporation, USA). The system is based on scanning white-light interferometry, a traditional technique in which a pattern of bright and dark lines (fringes) results from an optical path difference between a reference and a sample beam. Incoming light is split inside an interferometer, one beam going to an internal reference surface and the other to the sample. After reflection, the beams recombine inside the interferometer, undergoing constructive and destructive interference and producing the light and dark fringe pattern. In the used instrument, a precision vertical scanning transducer and camera together generate a three-dimensional interferogram of the surface, processed by computer and transformed by frequency domain analysis resulting in a quantitative 3-D image. This non-destructive technique allowed to measure roughness, waviness and curvature of the worn surface areas. The morphology of the differently worn areas was also observed with a scanning electron microscope, SEM (JEOL T330, Japan).
